Speaker: price
Dialogue: 'Morning, Jimmy, think you could squeeze me in?

Speaker: jimmy
Dialogue: Where is you would care to go at once, Mr. Price?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Bang-bang.

Speaker: jimmy
Dialogue: Twenty dollar.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: You're a thief, Jimmy.

Speaker: jimmy
Dialogue: Booteeful picture, huh, snap-snap?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I don't do skies.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Hi, guys.

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: G'damn, Price, you tuna sucking piece of raw meat -- whatchyou goin' to Zambeze for?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Thought I'd get some great shots of your head gettin' blown to smithereens.

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: Smithereens?! Be a great fuckin' picture, eh?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Be a prize winner.

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: I gotta have a joint.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I'm on the wagon, man, sorry.

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: Lotta fuckin' coons around here, eh?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I thought you were fighting for the Government?

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: I am. This is the Government.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: These are the Rebels.

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: Fuck they are. This is a Government convoy to Calunda.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: This is the Abou-Deian Revolutionary Front.

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: You're shitting me.

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: These guys be pissed if they knew, eh?  Nicaragua. That's the spot. Cheap shrimp, lotta rays -- real thin in the spook department too, dig?

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: Well hell... I wonder where the fuckin' Guvmint is?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Hold it! Hold it!

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: Well, I guess we know where the Guvmint is.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: You can walk to work from here.

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: Convenient, ain't it?

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: My brother just got married.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I don't know your brother.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: What's this?

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: Great shit, eh?

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: U.S. Gummint offers this house to any Cuban pilot flying Migs for the Rebels who chooses to defect to America with a Russian jet. We know they ain't gonna run off with no planes -- but the Rebs don't -- They're scared. They start thinking about that swimming pool. Damn near smell that chlorine. Starts workin' on 'em, and pretty soon they don't let the Cubies near a Mig. Use their own spook pilots and destroy their own air force in a week. Guaran-fuckin- teed.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: C.I.A.?

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: Hey, you gotta scoop here, eh? You'll be famous.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Maybe.

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: I gotta run... have a good one.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I love Africa.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: "...and so this strange war that features two provincial governments, three rival liberation fronts, and at least twenty-five tribal associations, grinds into its seventh year..."

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: "...The Battle for the Airfield at Abou Deia is just another chapter in this endless story. From Ndjamena, Chad, this is Claire Stryder."  No -- you didn't hear any music -- must be the connection. Okay? So long.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Alex, don't play that God damn thing when I'm filing.  We're late.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: It's my party -- we'll be late. You called it a "strange war" and an "endless story." If you filed that story for me, I'd say you were editorialishing.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I like to editorialize. You drunk?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Drunk? Only with the memories of making love with you on the plains of Fianga as the first Army of Liberation marched in and opened fire.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: And freed the Proletariat.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I'm going to the party without you.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Christ, I don't want to go to this stupid party. I'm bad at false modesty.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: You're great at it.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Alex, you're going to make a great anchorman in New York and undoubtedly I could be a Pulitzer Prize winning hostess -- but I'm not going with you.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: You can work out of the East Coast. We'll get a place on Long Island and burn our suitcases.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I still like suitcases.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Every Saturday night we'll have a party... invite all our friends, sit out on the veranda and interview each other.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I've done all that.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I haven't.  Well, God dammit, I'm getting tired of memorizing who's the president of the... Republic of Maldives.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Mamoon Abdul Gayoom.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Yeah, he succeeded Mamoon Abdul Gayeem.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: And I'm tired of Third World elevators.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Don't leave me.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I already have.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Fuck Abou Deia and New York. I'm going to Nicaragua with you.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I've heard it's a neat little war with a nice hotel.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Alex, get up here!

Speaker: price
Dialogue: To the man who gave me my first job, and fired me from my first job... and gave me my second job...

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Just a few words, Alex.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: You may be asking yourself what exactly are you doing here in this "strange war, just another chapter in an endless story... that grinds into its seventh year..."

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Oh. I didn't know you were here.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Sure you did. You were taking pictures of me all over the room.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Well... yeah... you looked great. Why aren't you partying?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: In a minute.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I printed that up for Alex.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: It wouldn't be the greatest thing you could give him right now...  We just split up.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Jesus, I'm sorry. Who left who this time?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I'm the villain... I thought it could be a little cleaner this time -- me in Central America, him in New York.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: That's pretty clean.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: But he's decided to go to Nicaragua too.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: To cover you or the war?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: To cover everything.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: For godsakes, Russell, listen.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I don't want to wait for you again. We've been circling each other since the Montreal Olympics.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: You're a genius of bad timing.  I'm going back to the party.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: This is a great shot.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I've heard the light in Nicaragua's even better.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Wait here.

Speaker: teenage boys
Dialogue: Rafael, Rafael, Rafael... libre o muerte... Rafael...

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Welcome to Managua.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: You have something to do with this?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Well... I thought of calling your photographs "Pictures from a Lost War"... I'm great at captions -- the New York editors loved it since none of them knew where the hell Chad was anyway -- it legitimized their ignorance, got you a cover, me a feature, and packaged a class struggle in two words. Nifty, eh?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Nifty.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I'm Russell Price.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I'm sorry... this is Isela Cruz. She works for the hotel and helps out as a translator.

Speaker: isela
Dialogue: My pleasure.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Looks like you guys have a lot of bang-bang down here, eh? Little misunderstanding between the poets and the government?

Speaker: isela
Dialogue: "Misunderstanding?!" "Down here" it's called a war. It started in nineteen thirty. Before you were born.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: My Spanish is a little out of shape -- what'd he say?

Speaker: isela
Dialogue: He said he considers it an honor to be able to photograph our war.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Russell's got a way with words.

Speaker: isela
Dialogue: I can tell.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: You're a helluva translator.

Speaker: isela
Dialogue: I know. I'm much in demand around here. Will you excuse me? If you have any questions, just ask.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Who is Rafael?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: It depends who you ask.

Speaker: isela
Dialogue: Rafael? Comandante Rafael. He is either a Marxist dupe of Russia and Cuba...  Take your pick.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I don't really give a damn... but the guy's got a great face.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: How would he like to be photographed?

Speaker: isela
Dialogue: You'd never find him.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Wanta lay odds?

Speaker: isela
Dialogue: You would lose.  You must excuse me.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Just one more thing -- is Rafael owned by the C.I.A. or the K.G.B.? I'll figure out the rest.

Speaker: isela
Dialogue: Mr. Price... the world is not divided into East and West anymore. It is divided into North and South. By the time you people figure that out -- it will be too late.  Congratulations on your cover.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: So far this war's got it all over Africa.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: You're gonna have a ball.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Hands off. I need an interpreter more than you do right now.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: You still hanging in there with Claire?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I'm hanging in there like an interim post-war government waiting for the palace to be overrun... by younger men.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Younger men.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Hi, Alex... Russell! When did you get in?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Just now.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: You're not going to believe this -- I just beat you guys and everybody else here to a story...  ...exclusive... eat your heart out.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: What'd ya get?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I've just been promised a private interview with Tacho.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Congratulations. The bastard won't talk to me.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Who's Tacho?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: That's President Somoza's nickname.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I don't know who the players are yet.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Want me to order you a hot dog and a program?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Fellas! No fighting after six at night, all right? Curfew.  C'mon, we've all got something to celebrate.

Speaker: boy photographer
Dialogue: Sometimes it doesn't work.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Let me look.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Ladeez and Gen'mun, hep me get Aaleex ov' here...

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: There's not many piano bars left where I'm still welcome.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Go ahead.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: If she can't sing in the key of C I'm in trouble.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Well...

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: "Well"... you finished your assignment in Chad?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Got Africa all wrapped up and pouched to my editor.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: You're going to love this war, Russell... there's good guys, bad guys, cheap shrimp...  I missed you.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: We gotta get alone somewhere to talk.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Sometimes I wonder why I spend these lonely nights, Dreaming of a song...

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Jesus... he's doing it on purpose.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Alex is one of the world's leading experts on military strategy.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Well, hell, I just got off the boat... gimme the scoop on Nicaragua...

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Well... about sixty years ago the U.S. Marines invaded to protect American business interests and put down a peasant revolt led by a little man who wore a giant cowboy hat -- his name was Augusto Sandino... In nineteen thirty-four he was murdered at a peace conference, and the Somoza family has ruled ever since...

Speaker: price
Dialogue: No, no, no... I don't mean the stuff about the peasants -- I mean the real stuff.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: The "real" stuff?... you mean a history of class struggle in agrarian societies?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: No, c'mon!

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Oh. Okay... well...

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Pecker?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Yeah... and throw it into Lake Managua.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Jesus.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: And the lake's already polluted.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Is there anybody here we don't know?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: regis
Dialogue: G'damn, Price... kudos on the African snaps.  Jeez, Claire, I haven't seen you since...

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Three Mile Island.

Speaker: regis
Dialogue: Yeah... shit...  Holiday Inn, right?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Jesus... Louis Jordan walks in, and I'm sitting with the Everly Brothers.

Speaker: regis
Dialogue: Before you fall in love -- that's Marcel Jazy... friend of wine, women, and Somoza. They say he's a businessman...

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: He's a businessman in search of a business... he doesn't try very hard to cover up his connections to the C.I.A...

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: But look at his moves -- can the C.I.A. light cigarettes like that?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: What's wrong with the Everly Brothers?

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: Please stay at your table, and you won't be hurt.

Speaker: guerrilla leader
Dialogue: We do not want to waste any ammunition on a head as empty as yours -- but we will.

Speaker: businessman
Dialogue: What is this?!

Speaker: guerrilla leader
Dialogue: Shut up! Get up!

Speaker: guerrilla leader
Dialogue: You are coming with us -- you will not be hurt -- we will trade you for the release of some Nicaraguans who care about Nicaragua.

Speaker: time stringer
Dialogue: ...it's Charlie, from New York -- says that a terrorist bombing of a Central American restaurant isn't big enough to hold for the world section...

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Tell him we have pictures.

Speaker: young journalist
Dialogue: He knows.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Tell him there were pieces of body in the piano, and somebody was singing, "I Left My Heart in San Francisco."  What's he got better than that?

Speaker: time stringer
Dialogue: He's got the Pope visiting Egypt.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Forget the Pope, Charlie. Every week you got the Pope somewhere. This is a very big story down here because it's the first sign of fighting in Managua.  Yeah, well get a map and look up Nicaragua -- ya drive to New Orleans and turn left.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Like hell I'm editorializing, the whole thing happened in a roomful of C.I.A. and press. What do you want?!  How do I know they were C.I.A.? They wore name tags, what do you think? We're backing a Fascist again -- I know that ain't news, but see if you can find an angle!

Speaker: hub
Dialogue: Hey! There's fascists and then there's fascists, right? Be careful how you throw words like that around.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: We don't have any pictures of Rafael because nobody knows where the son of a bitch is, and anybody crazy enough to go after him...

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: ...is liable to get his nuts shot off.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Yeah, well g'bye...  Who the fuck are you?

Speaker: hub
Dialogue: Hub Kittle. I'm with Lewitsky and Knupp -- New York. We have a client down here.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: hub
Dialogue: President Somoza.

Speaker: hub
Dialogue: I know, I know...  But there's an untold story here. I mean, the man has a point of view too, right?

Speaker: hub
Dialogue: We got a national anthem contest going on right now, and you guys are ignoring it. Lotta human interest.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I want you to get me copies of the Government inventory lists of all captured Guerrilla weapons. I want to know if the guns are Israeli, Belgian, Russian, Cuban...

Speaker: young woman
Dialogue: The Guerrillas are not supplied by anybody from the outside.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Fine -- give me proof.

Speaker: operator
Dialogue: Su hija, su hija! Your daughter from Los Angeles.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Hi, baby! How are you?  Yes, I got your letter with the picture of your new boyfriend. He's very good looking... but he's a bit old, isn't he? No? Just how old is he?...

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Cuanto?

Speaker: old woman
Dialogue: Quince.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Veinte.

Speaker: old woman
Dialogue: Diezysiete.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: What is this? I'm a journalist!

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Journalista, journalista!

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Padre Puta, Padre Puta, Padre Puta...  Here is a Priest for you to confess your sins.

Speaker: prisoner priest
Dialogue: Cigarillo?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Priest?  What are you doing here?

Speaker: prisoner priest
Dialogue: The government accused me of using the church to hide Rebels and guns.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Governments are always wrong, eh?

Speaker: prisoner priest
Dialogue: This time they're right. Who are you?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Un periodista.

Speaker: prisoner priest
Dialogue: Whose side are you on?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I don't take sides. I take pictures.

Speaker: prisoner priest
Dialogue: No sides?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: prisoner priest
Dialogue: Periodista Puta, todos periodistas son putas.

Speaker: prisoner priest
Dialogue: Go home.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Mi amigo -- mala interpretacion, eh? Periodista, comprende? Famoso. Time magazine.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Shut up!

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Soy un periodista.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: That film is half way to New York by now.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Forget it.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: You should be trying to seduce us!

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Senora...

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Claire!

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: You're okay?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I'm fine -- what're you doing here? These guys are goons.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: They love being beaten up by a woman  I've been looking for you all night -- why'd they lock you up?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I don't know. Taking pictures. The usual. Jazy got me released.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Jazy?! You think there's a story there?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Ahh... C.I.A. stories are all alike. I wanta find Rafael.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: You need help?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: No. You?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: No.  When should we start.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I figure you probably want to do a little research on the history of Marcel Jazy's business connections in the third world countries with C.I.A. influence...

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Oh. I assumed you'd just look him in the eye and say "Gimme a break, for crissakes, Marcel, are you a spy or aren't you?"

Speaker: price
Dialogue: ...are you a spy or aren't you, eh?

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: Spy is such an odd word, Mr. Price... nobody is a... 'spy'... anymore.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Russell prefers pictures to words...

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: You don't have to apologize... you're journalists.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: And you're a businessman?

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: A businessman? That sounds good. Okay, I'm a businessman.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Why was I arrested, and why did you get me released, and who are you?

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: No agua.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: If she dove in, I assure you she wouldn't notice.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: Sweetheart, the Guerrillas knocked out the pumping station on the road to Masaya, and we must ration water for the time being. Next week maybe things will be better.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: Maybe you should.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: You were arrested because the Guardia are clowns who specialize in excess. You were released because I told them to release you.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: These are not the normal duties of a businessman.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: But they are the normal duties of a... spy, eh? You win, I'm a spy.  There, are you happy? I feel better.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: Now we can relax. You can turn off your little thing.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: Oh, I trust you won't say anything to hurt me. In some ways I'm a terrible spy. I used to be much better at it, but now it seems everyone knows who I am. I have too many girlfriends. I like to be photographed.  I talk too much.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: I always talk too much... but my girlfriends like that... No matter.  You know who she is?

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: That's Miss Panama. Do you know who that is?

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: She's in love with me. I've got to get some water in the pool.  And once a week I have lunch with President Somoza to discuss security measures against the Sandinista insurgents, but all he wants to talk about is Miss Panama... he's worried about her.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Because he thinks she's seeing another man?

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: ...and he assigned me to find out who the man is.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: We all know the Revolutionaries are going to win, don't we?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: There's a rumor about this picture. Some people say you're a genius -- that you invented this scheme.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: It was lots of people's idea... Have you been to Leon?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: We're going to Masaya... they say the Rebels have hit the cuartel.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: It's supposed to be nasty there... a lotta people think Rafael's in the South. I want to find out.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: No, no, it's not "nasty" yet. Another week maybe.  You would love Leon. A nice cathedral and beautiful light... et un peu de bang-bang.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: We're not doing a travelogue, you understand.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: Of course, of course... only I have heard that Comandante Rafael has recently had his unit in the area.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Rafael is near Leon?

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: Well... it's a rumor, what do I know?

Speaker: miss panama
Dialogue: Estoy desemperado!

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: She's lonely!

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Don't let us stand in the way.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: It's my job.  You think I talk too much?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Did you dream about Miss Panama last night?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I dreamed about you.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Have a good time?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Yeah... so'd you.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: And old war injury flaring up?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Is the tape on?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I was on the deck of the U.S.S. Pueblo catching some rays when the North Koreans attacked... took a bullet right in the chest, but by luck I had an extra roll of high speed ektachrome in this pocket right here... over the heart...

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: And the bullet ricocheted off the film, grazed your cheek, and saved your life.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: You heard about it?! I was lucky.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Did anyone ever die next to you in combat?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: What did you do?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: F.8 at a sixtieth.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: That's an old joke. My question was serious.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: So was I.  You ever dream about me?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Once.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: How was I?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Fast.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I'm basically a coward, Russell, I hope you understand that. I hope we don't get shot.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Me too.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I thought it was quiet here.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Quiet? Are you sure you want to go down there? Not me.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: You must leave the car here.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: You thinking of scoring a Toyota?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: No problem -- we leave the car.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Now what?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: C'mon. Be careful.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Be careful?! Where the fuck we going? Better light?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: ...June tenth... the evacuation of Leon... a woman carries a pig... signs for the F.S.L.N. are everywhere... a body...

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Russell?!

Speaker: pedro
Dialogue: No, please...

Speaker: pedro
Dialogue: Americans? Journalists?

Speaker: pedro
Dialogue: Ah! I put my autograph on this ball.

Speaker: pedro
Dialogue: When you get back to the United States, I want you to give this ball to Tippy Martinez for me. He is from Nicaragua.

Speaker: pedro
Dialogue: Can they come with us?

Speaker: priest
Dialogue: No, please... it's not safe. You must come with me.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Price. You motherfucker, Price, I'm talking to you.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Where are those bastards... are they away?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: They're away.

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: What the fuck are you doing here?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: What the fuck are you doing here?

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: Awright, awright -- you're lookin' good... how ya like Nicaragua?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: It's beautiful.

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: Shitload o' greasers though, eh?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: You're okay?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Much better than Koufax.

Speaker: pedro
Dialogue: Koufax is okay... but Tippy Martinez, he is the best... he pitches for the Baltimore Orioles, and some day I will be the second man from Nicaragua to play in the major leagues...

Speaker: pedro
Dialogue: You will give my autographed baseball to Tippy and tell him in five years I will be pitching with him, okay? He better watch out for me, eh?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Gracias. Can they get into trouble for keeping us?

Speaker: pedro
Dialogue: No, no... you are not combatants.  The Baltimore team is my team...

Speaker: price
Dialogue: You bastard!

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: What about him?!

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Hello sweetheart, this is your mother. I'm in Leon and I miss you. Don't worry about me -- it's not dangerous at all. I guess you can't believe what you hear on the news. I'll put this this tape in the mail when I get back to Managua, but knowing what the mail service is like, I may be home before it arrives. I think about you all the time and hope I can make it back before you graduate from Jr. High.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I love you and I'll finish this letter when I get back to the hotel.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I know who shot Pedro. I knew somebody was in the tower.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Why didn't you tell the guerrillas?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I don't know... then they would've killed him I guess. I didn't want to interfere.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: It wasn't an easy choice.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I think I made the wrong one.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: You didn't take any pictures when it was over.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I didn't?  Is something happening to us?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Are you asleep?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: G'morning.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: You look beautiful.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: How long have you been doing this?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: 'Bout ten frames. Wait'll you see the pictures -- you look great.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I'll bet I look great -- give me the film.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: After they're printed.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I'll develop them myself -- give it to me or I'll start taping what you say in your sleep.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I talk in my sleep?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Girl's names and F-stops. Terrible.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Call the office. I don't want to go to work today.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: How was Matagalpa?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: You find anything?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Oh!

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Oh.  How was Leon?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Bloody.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Yeah... I'll bet... Claire...

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I'm tired of Nicaragua.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: You haven't been here very long.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Long enough, lets face it, you were right... everybody was right.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: About what?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: My cheekbones. What do you think of 'em?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I like your cheekbones. Alex, are you all right?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: This is a face made for television.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: You decided to go with the network.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Is he a good fuck?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Alex...

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: That's a reasonable question for a reporter to ask, isn't it?!  I shoulda never come down here, eh? This war down here belongs to you guys, okay? I'm on tommorrow's plane.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Alex...

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: You want to take me to the airport? It's okay.  I shoulda never come down here.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Take this to check in. I'll be right there.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Sniff this sucker, eh?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Jesus, where'd you get this?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: The C.I.A.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Where else.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Hey -- I'll leave you guys alone, eh?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: No, no, don't be ridiculous.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: We're grownups, Russell...  Most of us.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: You two wanta happy snap?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: No happy snaps.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Okay, okay...  I'll just... be over here.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: You're sure about him?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: For the moment.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Don't look, huh?  No mire!

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Don't get hurt.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Ahh, I'm a chicken, don't worry.  Alex, listen to me...

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Within a year you're gonna be one of the "Ten Most Admired Men in America."

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: You're late to your own luncheon, Mr. President -- we can schedule this for another time.

Speaker: somoza
Dialogue: Nonsense -- let them wait. We are a stunning couple, eh? My stomach is very flat -- I've been working out.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: We are a stunning couple. Mr. President, you own one fifth of all the land in Nicaragua, you own the shipping port, the national airlines, the Mercedes dealership...

Speaker: somoza
Dialogue: I am on a salt free diet...

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Do you always hold hands with reporters?

Speaker: somoza
Dialogue: This is my mother and father. They were very special to me. Every Sunday morning I drive out to the cemetery and put flowers on their grave. I think people should know that.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Would you care to comment on the fall of Leon to the rebels?

Speaker: hub
Dialogue: Listen, Russell, let's grow up. It's very easy to fall in love with the underdog, eh? But there's an upside and downside to this thing -- just wanta remind you... this stuff about a "Revolution of Poets" is crap.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: But it's great P.R. So what's the upside?

Speaker: hub
Dialogue: Simple. And it could happen. Somoza destroys the terrorist insurgents, rebuilds the country, shitcans the purveyors of excess, stabilizes the cordoba, and is finally beloved as the savior of Nicaragua.  Our pal. Got a smoke?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: What's the downside?

Speaker: hub
Dialogue: The Commies take over the world.

Speaker: hub
Dialogue: Excuse me, gentlemen, but the war may be over.

Speaker: somoza
Dialogue: My people love me. My stomach is flat. Did I say that already? No matter. It is flat.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: There are reports that the Guardia operates a torture chamber at Coyotepe.

Speaker: somoza
Dialogue: I like this song.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Since the earthquake in 1972 destroyed half of Managua, over three hundred million dollars in foreign relief aid have poured into the country, yet nothing has been re-built. It is said that the money has gone into your pocket.

Speaker: somoza
Dialogue: I love the press, I really do. Some of my best friends are journalists.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Ecuador, Mexico, Peru, Brazil, and Panama are reportedly on the verge of breaking off diplomatic relations with your regime. Would you comment?

Speaker: somoza
Dialogue: I am busy! Get out of here at once or I'll put my foot up your ass!

Speaker: somoza
Dialogue: I'm sorry to have to conclude this most pleasant encounter, but something has happened.

Speaker: hub
Dialogue: Did he tell you about his parents in the graveyard, the flowers and all that?  Good, good...

Speaker: somoza
Dialogue: My friends... this gathering was not intended to be a press conference as much as a... "get-together"... but I have just been handed a piece of news.

Speaker: somoza
Dialogue: Rafael is dead.  He has been killed in an ambush in the Cordillera mountains of the Jinotega district.

Speaker: journalists
Dialogue: Mr. President! Mr. President!

Speaker: somoza
Dialogue: Please my friends -- no questions. A press release is being prepared.

Speaker: other journalist
Dialogue: They got Rafael? You believe that?

Speaker: regis
Dialogue: Every six months Tacho gives this speech -- maybe they finally lucked out.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: Russell, excuse me... but I've just been put in a rather embarrassing position.  Mrs. Somoza would like her picture taken with Miss Panama. In color?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: How the hell could Tacho find Rafael.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: Russell, please... I have my hands full...

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Is Tacho lying again? They did kill him, didn't they?

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: Everybody smile.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: One more, please! Una mas, por favor?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: We help each other, right? Could you move your girlfriend into the sun...

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: What do you need?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Is Rafael alive or dead?

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I thought you knew everything?

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: What do I know, eh? Tacho needs a victory very badly... he needs to prove to Jimmy Carter that he is still winning. He thinks Rafael's death is the proof he needs.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Carter don't need proof. He just sent twenty-five million in new arms to Tacho.  I'm sorry... almost got it here.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: No, no... the arms shipment has been delayed in New Orleans because Jimmy is getting nervous.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: The State Department's gonna pull the plug on Tacho?! Pardon my French -- but whose fucking side are you on?

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: ...I work for everybody. If there is a transition of power, I facilitate a relationship with the new people. If there is not, I facilitate the status quo.  Either way, I facilitate.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Great job.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: I send messages to Jimmy and I tell him that the Revolution is a flood that cannot be stopped but it can be controlled... nobody listens... I can't even get a little water in my pool.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Rough ain't it. Thank you everybody, very nice.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I don't think Rafael is dead. I'm gonna find him.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: They say he's very handsome.  It would make a wonderful picture, eh?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Con permiso -- who controls what today?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: How do we find the guerillas?

Speaker: regis
Dialogue: What'd he say?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Go two or three blocks and turn right at the sniper.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: You can drop us off.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Wrong way!

Speaker: regis
Dialogue: We're not looking for the guerillas.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Then let us out.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Lo siento!

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Go one more block.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: He just wanted to see credentials, for crissakes, what're doing?

Speaker: regis
Dialogue: You want to drive?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: We want out!

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Periodista, periodista, periodista!

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: Busca triquitraques?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Si.

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: Venga.

Speaker: isela
Dialogue: You are looking for Rafael?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Yeah. If it's possible.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Do you know why we're here... exactly?

Speaker: isela
Dialogue: Mr. Price doesn't do anything before announcing it first in the bar.  It's a good story. You'll be more famous.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Rafael's tent?

Speaker: isela
Dialogue: Venga, companeros.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Rafael is dead.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I can smell it.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: isela
Dialogue: Venga por favor! Alli!

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: What're you talking about?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: He's dead. I know it.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Then why did they bring us all the way here to see him?

Speaker: isela
Dialogue: This is Commandante Cinco.

Speaker: isela
Dialogue: Today we took Matagalpa. Leon is about to fall, and Masaya. And next week we could be in Managua but it is still possible to lose.  In the last days of our final offensive the people of Nicaragua must know that Rafael is alive and well.

Speaker: commandante cinco
Dialogue: Queremos un fotografia.

Speaker: isela
Dialogue: We need a photograph.  Come with us.

Speaker: commandante cinco
Dialogue: Usted es un fotografo magnifico.

Speaker: isela
Dialogue: Why is he laughing?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: You're crazy.

Speaker: cinco
Dialogue: We have momentum, but many more lives will be lost. Even Washington is starting to admit that the butcher Somoza is not loved by his people. They have detained twenty-five million dollars in new arms shipments for Somoza at an airfield in Florida until they find out if Rafael is alive or dead. We know about these things.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: If Washington thinks Rafael is dead, they will ship the arms to Somoza. Do you understand.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Yeah.  Commandante... Soy un periodista.

Speaker: cinco
Dialogue: This has nothing to do with journalism -- there is more to the world than journalism. We are going to end this war with you or without you.  People don't really believe in Rafael -- they believe in the idea of Rafael, no? Because for now the idea of Rafael is enough for the people of Nicaragua. When the war is over -- none of this matters.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I don't do things... like this.

Speaker: cinco
Dialogue: Enough lives have been lost already.  It's difficult, I know -- but you must do it.

Speaker: cinco
Dialogue: In the morning, eh? When there's better light!

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I spend my whole life separating how I feel from how I think and what I see from what I say -- that's called journalism, isn't it?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: It's disciplined. It civilized. It involves distinctions. I'm great at distinctions. I wish I wasn't so good at them. Sometimes I envy you -- you don't make any -- it's very convenient.  The only time I don't worry about all those things is when I'm with my daughter.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Or when you're in bed.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Yes!  That's a very romantic streak I have running through me -- maybe it's a weakness. Information is good -- lack of information is bad. Simple, eh?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Not so simple.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: You're God damn right it's not.  You take that picture you'll take it for all the right reasons -- I understand.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I'm not gonna take it.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: That's fine for you. But do I go back and say I interviewed Rafael? Do I go back and say I missed the biggest story of the war? Or do I say Rafael was stone cold dead -- that's the information, isn't it? Or do I say he entertained us all in his inimitably charismatic manner around the ol' revolutionary campfire?  Which story do you want me to tell?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Do what you want to do.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Christ, what the fuck are we doing here?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I want to be here.  What do you want.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I want this war to end.  I'm not going to tell the world that Rafael is dead.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I love you.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I think I love you.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Don't think so much.

Speaker: miss panama
Dialogue: Marcel!

Speaker: regis
Dialogue: We got the smoke in frame?

Speaker: crewmember
Dialogue: We got the smoke.

Speaker: regis
Dialogue: Roll it...

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Under a steel gray July sky... start again... under a gray steel Managuan sky... scratch it... In an extraordinary development in Managua, President Anastazio Somoza has ordered the Air Force to begin bombing his own capitol, under a sky... fuck it...

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Oh my God...

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: A Scotch, please...  Double.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: What's he doing here?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I have no idea.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Congratulations.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: On what?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: On what?! The Washington Post, the Times, networks, wire services -- everybody's picked up the picture. It's fabulous.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Well, yes... it's fabulous.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Fabulous.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Why are you back?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I came back because of Russell.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Because of me?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Yeah... the whole fucking East Coast is falling in love with Rafael -- they were sure he was dead this time. Somebody wants to do a musical about him and his mug's on every T-shirt in Central Park.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I think he's bigger than Farrah Fawcett.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: You look good. Things're okay?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I'm happier in New York, sure, things are great. You guys?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Terrific... now... I'm a little slow here, Alex... what exactly did you come back for?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: It's a great story.  I want to talk to Rafael... and you're the only man in the world that can take me to him.

Speaker: hub
Dialogue: Alex! Couldn't stay away, eh?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: We've got to tell Alex what happened.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: No way.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I'll tell him. He deserves to know.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: We don't owe him anything!

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: We owe him that!  He took care of you before you were hot!

Speaker: price
Dialogue: He wouldn't understand.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Before Nicaragua you wouldn't understand. I'm not sure I exactly understand.  What are we going to do?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I'll take Alex to find Rafael -- we'll go to Sebaco on the road to Matagalpa -- the Guardia heavily control the area and they're scared right now -- they'll never let us through. We won't be able to get near Rafael. Alex will understand -- and we'll turn around and drive back without a story.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: That's a lie!

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Tell me about lies!

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I don't want to tell him either.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: We may not be able to find him, y'know...

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I've got supreme confidence in you.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Claire looks good, eh?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Everybody looks good in the tropics.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Since I haven't been able to find Isela since coming back, you're going to have to translate for me -- what the hell does that mean?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Alex... I love her.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: And she 'thinks' she loves you.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: It's past the thinking stage.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I'd like to know something -- it probably doesn't matter in the great final scheme of things... but I'm interested...  Did you ever lay a hand on her before she left me?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: That's the truth?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Yes!  Alex -- we're friends!

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Venga.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I bet you go through a few rental cars.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Don't worry. I put this in your name.

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: No pictures, eh? Might look bad.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: You get paid by the body or by the hour?

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: I get paid the same way you do. What the fuck you doin' in Sebaco -- this place's about to blow... ain't it?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: You didn't have to nail Pedro.

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: Who's Pedro?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Oh my God...

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: There's a motherfucking war goin' on, pal... lotta sad stories.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Why them? Why them?!

Speaker: price
Dialogue: You're a cocksucker!

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: I don't suck no dick, man...

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: I'd prefer not splattering your brains in a dump like this -- I got priorities.  Who are you?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Russell, let's get outta here.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Fuck you.

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: Guy's got a sense of humor, old man.  Got any dope? Tough place to find decent dope?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Why them?

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: Them? C'mere. You too.

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: If your mug shows up in this box... and ya try to make it through Sebaco... I owe yer ass.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Who gives you the pictures?

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: What's this, an interview? I ain't that dumb.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Off the record.

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: Off the record... some pachuco gives 'em to me. Ain't none of my business, but I heard he gets 'em from a Frog.

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: Nice, eh?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: She dead?

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: Not yet.

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: Whatya' expect? We're the ones gettin' our butts kicked.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Some-motherfucker-took-my-fucking- pictures-I-don't-fucking-know-what- happened!  Fuck me!

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Didn't you ship the film to New York?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I developed it in my room.  Jesus Christ, Alex?!

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Slow down.  It wasn't your fault if somebody stole your stuff...

Speaker: price
Dialogue: It was.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: What about Rafael?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Algo no esta aqui. Fotografias.

Speaker: maid
Dialogue: Everything's always a mess here. You should be neater.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Negativos, negativos!

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Commandante Cinco's body was just found on the road to Matagalpa.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I don't think it's Jazy.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Oates said it was a Frog. How many Frenchmen you know around here? Jazy ain't 'facilitating' shit.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Christ!

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Are we looking for negs or prints?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Anything.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Que quiere?

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Donde esta senor Jazy?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: No esta aqui.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Que quienes?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: No, no, no...

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Russell?  Russell?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Let's get out of here.

Speaker: miss panama
Dialogue: Hola.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: We've got to talk to Alex.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: You think our flags are big enough?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: This is what I want to show you.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: We drove through three roadblocks a half hour before curfew so you could show me a statue of Tacho.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: It's not Tacho. It's Mussolini. Tacho went to Italy to commission a statue of himself, he found a warehouse full of Il Duces on horseback, got a great deal on one of 'em -- brought it back and switched heads.  Ya can't tell, can ya?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: What the hell are you talking about?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I think what he's trying to say -- what we're trying to say -- is that things aren't exactly what they seem to be.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Well, they don't "seem" to be that great so I can't wait for this one...  Hey, here we are! Two guys in the tropics in love with the same dame... bullets flying!

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Alex! That's not why we're here.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Oh yeah? I left the country because of him...  What are we doing here?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Rafael is dead.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: In the picture he's dead?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Dead!

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: How the hell...

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Who cares how?!

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Alex... I think I finally saw one too many bodies.  How many reasons do you want?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: You saw too many bodies? That's a lot of bodies.  Did he talk you into it?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: No! I wanted Rafael to be alive.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: In some way I understand him doing it, I don't like it but I understand... but you?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I'd do it again.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: You two have, of course, just served me up your balls -- if that's what they're called -- on a platter.  I can bury you both. You're handing me your careers.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Well, Jesus Christ... this is a motherfucking story, Russell...  What am I supposed to do with it?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Anything you want.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: They're holding the lead in the World section for Rafael.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: It's great stuff, isn't it? We'd go down in a blaze of glory.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Oh yeah...  I've gotta take some kind of a story back with me. Maybe Jazy, eh?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Oh Jesus.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: It's a little dangerous looking for Jazy at the moment.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Ah, danger -- I love it. You could ask the pointy-shoed little bastard about your pictures... and I could ask him whatever happened to Isela.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: She's an officer in the Rafael army -- we saw her in Matagalpa.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: You mean I slept with a Sandinista?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I guess Rafael is alive, eh?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Damn air conditioning.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I wish I was home.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: C'mere.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Do you think it's almost over?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Alex... let's go back.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Jazy's probably sitting in the bar laughing at us. Which way's the hotel?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I'll ask her... be right back.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Just a sec'... take a flag.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: You fucks! You fucks!

Speaker: guardia soldier
Dialogue: Fotografia!

Speaker: somoza
Dialogue: It is with grave concern that we announce that Alexander Grazier, senior American correspondent, has been murdered at the hands of terrorists...

Speaker: somoza
Dialogue: Mr. Kittle has prepared statements for you.

Speaker: regis
Dialogue: Get my bill and get me a cab, hey, amigo!

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: No cabs.

Speaker: regis
Dialogue: Cabs!

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: No cabs!

Speaker: regis
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Claire...

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Heard from Russell?

Speaker: regis
Dialogue: Nobody has.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Wanta help me find him?

Speaker: regis
Dialogue: Claire... it's on the weird side out there...

Speaker: hub
Dialogue: Jesus Christ, Claire, a human tragedy, what can I say?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Fuck off, Hub, get outta my way.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Do you know where the American journalist was killed?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Have you seen him?

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: This is the best I can offer.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Gracias.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Venga aqui.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Nobody is here. Get out.

Speaker: leader
Dialogue: Esta alli?!

Speaker: leader
Dialogue: Esta alli?!

Speaker: boy soldier
Dialogue: No esta aqui.

Speaker: guardia officer
Dialogue: We are you! We are you! What are you doing?!

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Russell!

Speaker: price
Dialogue: What're you doing here?!

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Alex!

Speaker: price
Dialogue: The Guardia did it -- I got pictures.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Hola.  Do you control this area?

Speaker: disco sandinista
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: They are my friends.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: Well, here we are, eh?

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: The boys are confused -- they think I had their family killed.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: You murder people.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: "Murder" is a word for criminals. I have a job to protect the stability of a continent.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: Please...

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: You got caught by some boys?

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: Yes. Poets too, I imagine.  Is your recorder on?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: Good. I have a speech to make.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: I like you people, but you are sentimental shits. You fall in love with the poets, the poets fall in love with the Marxists, the Marxists fall in love with themselves. The country is destroyed with rhetoric, and in the end we are stuck with tyrants.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: Un minuto, por favor.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: They are journalists.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: Somoza? He is a tyrant too, of course. A butcher.  But finally that is not the point, you see. If we wish to survive -- we have a choice of tyrants, and for all the right reasons, your poets choose the wrong side.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: Yes.  Muy complicado, no?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: You picked the wrong side.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: In fifty years we will know who's right.  Are you going to take the picture as the bullet enters the skull or as it comes out? This wall's a nice color, eh? I can move into the sunlight.

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: It's just a story!

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: They say that if somebody's holding a gun on you, you should never stop talking... that's the theory -- who knows?...

Speaker: jazy
Dialogue: Maybe it's a good thing that I talk too much...

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: You okay?  Russell... what did Alex do?

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Nothing. He asked for directions.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: We gotta get outta sight -- half the fucking army's looking for me...

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: They're not looking for me.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Let me have the film...  ...if I can't get to the hotel I'll come back here...

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Aw, Christ...  I've wrecked everything else, at least let me take care of you here.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Russell... it's more dangerous being with you than being alone.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Don't get hurt.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: That's great advice.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Journalist?  Perhaps now Americans will be outraged at what is happening here, eh?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Yes... perhaps they will.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Maybe we should have killed an American journalist fifty years ago.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Have you seen La Guardia?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: child
Dialogue: Tanquettas! Tanquettas!

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Alex.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Can you help us ship it home?

Speaker: hub
Dialogue: I've already taken care of it.  I always liked the guy. I can't even get tickets for my own family, but I could get you two on the plane if you want.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: Yes, please...

Speaker: hub
Dialogue: Tacho's in Miami.

Speaker: hub's daughter
Dialogue: Daddy!

Speaker: hub
Dialogue: I am sorry. I had a job to do -- that's all -- it put me in some unhappy situations.

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: Hey, Pricey...

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: It's all over, eh? We made it. I like the singing.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: What're you doing here?

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: Free country. Now it's free, anyway.  Nicalibre!

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: How 'bout a quickie?  You ain't gonna turn me in, are ya?

Speaker: oates
Dialogue: Am I gonna see ya in Thailand? We could be friends!

Speaker: price
Dialogue: We've got a plane to catch.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Did you get enough pictures?
